captions.text:
Laurie, what in the hell
are you doing in there?

- Is she gonna ride with you?
- Mind your own business,John.

Yeah, she's going with me.
You take care of yourself, man.
You guys ready?
You son of a bitch!
Come on, she's gonna blow.

I don't know.
Please, don't come near me.

I'm gonna be sick.
Oh, Steven.

Oh, Steven!
Please don't leave me.

- Don't leave me, please.
- I won't.

I couldn't bear it.
Please.
I'm not gonna leave you.

- I'm not gonna leave you.
- Promise me.

- I promise.
- Do you?
I'm not gonna leave you.

That was beautiful, John.
Just beautiful.

- I was losin', man.
- What?

He was pulling away from me
just before he crashed.

You're crazy! You creamed him
from right off the line.

Shit, Toad! The man had me.
He was beatin' me.

John, I don't know
what you're talking about.

It was the most beautiful thing
I've ever seen.

title: American Graffiti (10/10) Movie CLIP - Drag Race at Paradise Road (1973) HD

comments.author: wrotenwasp

comments.text:
Best movie drag race ever and will always be the greatest if you lived 
during that time up to the mid 70's and I can remember doing this and 
burning ssome ass with a couple of cars,but I got burned afew times 
myself..Best I ever had was a 1971 Model J Gran Prix with a stock  400 
4barrel and man it knock out 100 thru the 1/4 mile every time you run that 
bitch and it was a big heavy car that run like scalded dog with turpintine 
up its ass!!I scared the hell out of people taking for rides in it on the 
highway with curves and shit,like a damn rocket running the odometer pegged 
at 140mph and I got a ticket for 135mph and Sheriff got me out of it!We met 
them and old boy that was with me said shit they looking for me and Carl 
just looked me in the face(Sheriff),said want to try and out run them?He 
said go for it and I hold on cause we gonna be moving like hell on fire!! I 
was trying to outrun a State Trooper who I wont name that day but they were 
after a fellow riding with me..Asked the Sheriff what he had done and said 
 he had stole aload of logs and sold them,then he told me he would take 
care of the ticket and he did...One they were after had to be messed up 
when they got him to jail,he had some damn pills and took all them at 
once!!Me I wasn't into no drugs and never  smoked pot until late 1978 and 
then it wasn't that bad a thing to do..Cain-pole as they called the 1 they 
were after,hell he would do anything for a  high!!!!To the old  days 
Cain-pole and Sharon Cain no relation to him,she was skipping school and 
man I got an ass chewing for having her along from what was my girlfriend 
at the time and then in 1982 become my wife just to get away from home and 
then dropped me for a drunk that beat her and now she finally divorced his 
sorry ass!!GOOD FUCKIN' BYE BITCH!!﻿

comments.text:
At mark 1:45 the 55 Chevy is upside down and you can see the transmission 
pan. IT is a Turbo 400, which was introduced by GM in 1964 for Cadillac. It 
was later on before GM installed them in their other lines.  If this movie 
was based on the late 50's time frame then the transmission in that vehicle 
was ahead of its time. BAHAHAHAHAHAHA﻿

comments.author: TheHemiDodge426

comments.text:
+Shane S The 454 wasn't introduced til 1970. The 409 big block is what was 
available in '62. '63 was a different story but the movie was set in '62. 

A 409-cubic-inch (6.7 L) version was Chevrolet's top regular production 
engine from 1961 to 1965, with a choice of single or dual four-barrel 
carburetors. Bore and stroke were both up from the 348 to 4.312 in (109.5 
mm) by 3.50 in (88.9 mm). On December 17, 1960, the 409 engine was 
announced along with the Impala SS (Super Sport) model. The initial version 
of the engine produced 360 hp (268 kW), with a single four-barrel Carter 
AFB carburetor. The same engine was upped to 380 hp (283 kW) in 1962. A 409 
hp (305 kW) version of this engine was also available, developing 1 hp per 
cubic inch with a dual four-barrel aluminum intake manifold and two Carter 
AFB carburetors. It had a forged steel crankshaft.[1]

In the 1963 model year, output reached 425 hp (317 kW) at 6200 rpm with the 
2X4 setup, 11.25:1 compression and a solid lifter camshaft. This engine was 
immortalized in the Beach Boys song titled "409". The engine was available 
through mid-1965, when it was replaced by the 396-cubic-inch 425 hp (317 
kW) Mark IV big-block engine. In addition, a 340 hp (254 kW) version of the 
409 engine was available from 1963–1965, with a single four-barrel 
cast-iron intake mounting a Rochester 4GC square-bore carburetor, and a 
hydraulic-lifter camshaft.

Obviously the premise was that Milner's engine was a highly modified small 
block in its '62 setting. Bear in mind that at that time there were 292 ci 
small blocks revving to the stars propelling '55 Chevy 210 Sedans at the 
strip at the time to amazing ET numbers for their day...

comments.text:
There were three 55 Chevys. The one from Two Lane Blacktop. The second car 
was also from Two Lane Blacktop. It was built for a crash scene that was 
never filmed. The third 55 was pulled out of a junkyard. The stunt car was 
used for the actual race and crash. The junkyard car was the one that 
actually burned. The stunt car was salvaged and became a dirt track car.﻿

I think the scenario in the movie was a tire blowout made him lose control, 
but all of that torque can make a car get very squirrely even without a 
blowout.  The are many videos online of drag races where one or both of the 
cars suddenly get loose about halfway down the track and they hit the wall, 
each other, roll over, etc. It can get very ugly.

comments.text:
My Dad bought a "new" black 56 Chevy that had a Smokey Yunick small block 
engine.  When an out-of-town cop got after him, he'd leave them in the 
dust.  This '55 for the movie had a 427 big block with dual carbs, thus the 
need for the raised hood intake...I think I have that right.﻿
comments.author: joltinjack

comments.text:
The stories are conflicting, but I've read from several sources that there 
were three '55s used in the movie - two "runners" and a junker for the 
rollover scene.  Of the two runners, one had a 427 and the other a 454, and 
the primary runner (427) was also used in the movie Two Lane Blacktop.

Of course, in real life Falfa's '55 couldn't have had either of those 
engines in the summer of '62.  The first generation W-series 427 didn't 
debut until the fall of '62 as an RPO for the '63 Impala, and apparently 
only 50 were produced. It could have had a 348 or an early 409, or maybe 
more likely, a 283 or a "new for '62" 327. Then it would all come down to 
power to weight ratio, gearing, reaction time, and the ability to hook up 
at launch.

comments.text:
I was into street racing a 1965 GTO when this movie came out and we were 
nice to our rivals but something happened the next town over that was not 
usual. A Chevelle and a Mustang decided to run for $100, the Mustang 
wrecked and driver killed, the Chevelle came back reached in took the guys 
wallet pulled a $100 bill out and threw the wallet back onto the dead guy! 
We didn't know the jerk but that wasn't usual behavior with us racers, so 
sad! We even tried to help the cops track the guy down! True story from my 
street racing days!﻿

comments.text:
+chase gibbins
He took the plugs out, meaning the exhaust should be coming out the side. 
With the plugs in it went through the full exhaust to the back but with the 
plugs out he would be using the side pipes.
comments.author: Grant Sondgeroth

comments.text:
he has an exhaust that opens up at the headers and then is capped off by a 
removable cover. then goes on back to the full exhaust. if you have seen 
the movie you notice whenever he leaves the station right before this race 
the guy says "i see you took your header plugs out john" and you also 
notice the car got louder.
comments.author: chase gibbins

comments.text: i hope that wasnt the actual car they flipped...﻿
comments.author: Brian Griffin

comments.text: Wish i could get ahold of onr for 500$
comments.author: chase gibbins

comments.text:
55 Chevys as desirable as they were even back in 1972 when this was filmed 
were still numerous so it was no biggie if they were wrecked. because there 
were plenty around and the car itself could be bought for less than $500 
before modifications.
comments.author: Mark Muffs

comments.text:
+wulff707 wasnt the same car, they made 2. well 3. 2 for 2 lane and one for 
graffiti. one of the ones from 2 lane was a camera car and the other was 
the car with a bad ass 454 like this one. they were made by the same person 
tho. there is only 2 sets of headers like the ones on those 2 cars. one on 
the main 454 car in 2 lane and one on the 55 in graffiti.
comments.author: chase gibbins

comments.text:
yeah i know the history of that car (great flick btw) thats why i was 
hoping that wasnt the one they flipped
comments.author: Brian Griffin

comments.text:
If you ever saw '2-lane blacktop' that was the same car, it had a later 
model 454 in it and what happened to it is almost as sad as rolling it. A 
guy with big bucks on the east coast bought it and turned it into a custom! 
Milners car is still around and the guy takes it to A.G. shows all the time!
The 55 that rolled has a single exhaust and it was a Bel-Air without the 
posts, they made some posts out of wood to make it look like a post type 
210.
comments.author: wulff707

comments.text: It was not.

Parsecs!﻿
